\begin{abstract}
In  \cite{HPP}, Hrushovski and the authors proved, in a certain finite rank environment, that rigidity of definable Galois groups implies that $T$ has the canonical base property in a strong form; `` internality to"  being replaced by ``algebraicity in".  In the current paper we  give a reasonably robust definition of the ``strong canonical base property" in  a  rather more general finite rank context than \cite{HPP}, and prove its {\em equivalence}  with rigidity of the relevant definable Galois groups.  The new direction is an elaboration on the old result that $1$-based groups are rigid.



\end{abstract}

\maketitle

\section{Introduction}

In a stable theory, a set $X$ which is type-definable over a small set of parameters $A$,  is called $1$-based if for any tuple $b$ of elements of $X$ and set $B$ of parameters containing $A$, the canonical base of ${\mathrm{stp}}(b/B)$ is contained  in ${\mathrm{acl}}(b,A)$.  If $X = G$ happens to be a type-definable group then $1$-basedness of $G$ implies {\em rigidity} of $G$, which means that every connected type-definable subgroup of $G$ is type-definable over ${\mathrm{acl}}(A)$ \cite{HP}.  But rigidity of $G$ does not imply $1$-basedness: for example in ${\rm ACF}_{0}$ semiabelian varieties are rigid, but not $1$-based.


Recently, relative versions of one-basedness have come into play.

The main example is the canonical base property (CBP), which originates in \cite{pil02} and \cite{PZ}, was formally defined in \cite{MooPil}, and also studied by Chatzidakis \cite{zoe}, and in a more general framework by Palac\'in and Wagner \cite{pal-wag}, where (a weak version of) the CBP is indeed treated as a generalization of one-basedness.

The CBP, as formulated in \cite{MooPil} is a  property appropriate to {\em finite rank} stable theories $T$ and says (of $T$) that for any tuple $b$ and set of parameters $B$,  if $c$ is the canonical base of ${\mathrm{stp}}(b/B)$, then ${\mathrm{stp}}(c/b)$ is almost  internal to  the family of ${\mathrm{U}}$-rank $1$ types (or equivalently, to the  family of nonmodular ${\mathrm{U}}$-rank $1$  types).  The CBP  holds of the many-sorted theory ${\rm CCM}$ of compact complex spaces (see \cite{pil02}) as well as the finite Morley rank part of the  theory ${\rm DCF}_0$ of differentially closed fields of characteristic $0$ (see \cite{PZ}). Moreover, as pointed out in \cite{PZ},  this ${\rm DCF}_{0}$ case yields a quick account of function field Mordell-Lang in characteristic $0$.




In the joint paper with Hrushovski \cite{HPP} an example appears of a finite rank, in fact $\aleph_{1}$-categorical theory, where the CBP fails.  Now if $T$ is  an  $\aleph_{1}$-categorical theory, then the obstruction to $T$ being almost strongly minimal is given by infinite definable Galois groups (using the theory of analyzability and definable automorphism groups), of which precise definitions will be given below.  Similarly for finite rank nonmultidimensional theories.
In \cite{HPP} we worked, for convenience, with finite rank theories $T$ which are ``coordinatised"  by strongly minimal formulas over $\emptyset$, and proved that if all relevant definable Galois groups are rigid then $T$ has the CBP in the strong form that whenever
 $c = {\mathrm{Cb}}({\mathrm{stp}}(b/c))$, then $c$ is contained in the algebraic closure of $b$ and realizations of strongly minimal formulas over $\emptyset$.  (This was generalized in \cite{pal-wag2} using results in \cite{zoe}).  In the current paper we  give a robust definition of  $T$ having the {\em strong canonical base property} in a setting somewhat more general than that considered in \cite{HPP}, and prove its a equivalence with the rigidity of the relevant definable Galois groups (see Theorem \ref{ThmFinRank} in Section 3).
 In Section 2, we give a ``local" version of the equivalence between rigidity and the strong CBP  (see Theorem \ref{ThmRigid}).







We will assume familiarity with stability theory and geometric stability theory, and  the reader is referred to \cite{PilBook}. Nevertheless, we give here a brief discussion of some of the key notions of this paper.
We shall be working inside a monster model $\mathfrak M^{\rm eq}$ of a first-order stable theory $T$. Sometimes we talk about global types, namely complete types over this monster model. If $b$ is a tuple and $B$ a set of parameters then the canonical base of ${\mathrm{stp}}(b/B)$, which we denote ${\mathrm{Cb}}({\mathrm{stp}}(b/B))$,  is the smallest definably closed (in $\mathfrak M^{\rm eq}$) subset $C$ of ${\mathrm{acl}}(B)$ such that $b$ is independent from ${\mathrm{acl}}(B)$ over $C$ and ${\mathrm{tp}}(b/C)$ is stationary. We often identify $C$ with a tuple enumerating it, or with a tuple with which it is interdefinable.  Sometimes we write ${\mathrm{Cb}}(b/B)$ for ${\mathrm{Cb}}({\mathrm{stp}}(b/B))$. When $T$ is totally transcendental ${\mathrm{Cb}}({\mathrm{stp}}(b/B))$ can be taken to be a finite tuple.


Let us  fix a family ${\mathcal Q}$ of partial types over  small sets of parameters. For $B$ a set of parameters, we say $a$ realizes ${\mathcal Q}$ over $B$ if there is a partial type $\Psi$ in ${\mathcal Q}$ over a set of parameters contained in $B$ and $a$ realizes $\Psi$.

Let $p$ be a stationary type over a set $A$. We say that $p$ is {\em (almost) internal to ${\mathcal Q}$} if there
is a superset $B$ of $A$, some realization $a$ of $p|B$ (the unique nonforking extension of $p$ over $B$), and a
tuple $\bar b$ of realizations of  ${\mathcal Q}$ over $B$ such that $a\in{\mathrm{dcl}}(B,\bar b)$ (or $a\in{\mathrm{acl}}(B,\bar b)$, respectively).

Internality gives rise to Galois groups (possibly trivial) typically when $p\in S(A)$ and ${\mathcal Q}$ is a family of partial types over $A$.  In this case we sometimes identify ${\mathcal Q}$ with the union of the sets of realizations of the partial types in ${\mathcal Q}$.  Let ${\mathcal Q}$ be such, and let $p\in S(A)$ be stationary and internal to ${\mathcal Q}$. Then according to Lemma 7.4.2 of \cite{PilBook}, there exists an
$A$-definable function $f(\bar x,\bar y)$, partial types types $\Psi_0,\ldots,\Psi_n$ in ${\mathcal Q}$ and
some tuple $\bar a$ of realizations of $p$ such that,  for any realization $a$
of $p$ there is a tuple $\bar c=(c_0,\ldots,c_n)$ with $c_i$ realizing $\Psi_i$
such that $a=f(\bar a,\bar c)$. The tuple $\bar a$ is usually called a {\em
fundamental system of solutions} of $p$ relative to ${\mathcal Q}$.   This is   required to
 obtain the following result, which is \cite[Theorem 7.4.8]{PilBook}, and due to Hrushovski at this level of generality, although in more special cases (such as $\aleph_{1}$-categorical theories) it was observed by Zilber.

\begin{fact}\label{FactGal}
If ${\mathcal Q}$ is a family of partial types over $A$ and $p$ is a stationary type over $A$ internal to ${\mathcal Q}$, then there is an
$A$-type-definable group $G$ and an $A$-definable action of $G$ on the set of
realizations of $p$ which is naturally isomorphic (as a group action) to the
group ${\mathrm{Aut}}(p/{\mathcal Q},A)$ of permutations of the set of realizations of $p$ induced by the
automorphisms of $\mathfrak M$ fixing $A\cup {\mathcal Q}$ pointwise.




\end{fact}

We call the group $G$ from Fact \ref{FactGal} the {\em (type-)definable Galois group of $p$ relative to ${\mathcal Q}$}, and identify it with
${\mathrm{Aut}}(p/{\mathcal Q},A)$; sometimes it is also called the liason group or binding group.
Observe that whenever $p$ is internal to ${\mathcal Q}$ and $\bar a$ is a fundamental system
of solutions of $p$ relative to ${\mathcal Q}$, ${\mathrm{tp}}(\bar a/A)$ is also internal to ${\mathcal Q}$,  $G = {\mathrm{Aut}}(p/{\mathcal Q},A)$ acts (definably over $A$)  on the
set of realizations of ${\mathrm{tp}}(\bar a/A)$, and moreover coincides with ${\mathrm{Aut}}({\mathrm{tp}}(\bar a/A)/{\mathcal Q},A)$. Also, an easy argument (see

Claim I of \cite[Theorem 7.4.8]{PilBook}) yields that




\begin{fact}\label{FactFree}
The type-definable group ${\mathrm{Aut}}(p/{\mathcal Q},A)$ acts freely on the set of realizations of
${\mathrm{tp}}(\bar a/A)$, that is for some/any realization $\bar b$ of ${\mathrm{tp}}(\bar a/A)$, and $\sigma\in  {\mathrm{Aut}}(p/{\mathcal Q},A)$, $\sigma$ is determined by $\sigma(\bar b)$.
\end{fact}

This observation plays an essential role in the proof of Lemma \ref{PropGal}. On the other hand
observe that there is no reason why ${\mathrm{Aut}}(p/{\mathcal Q},A)$ should act freely on
the set of realizations of ${\mathrm{tp}}(a/{\mathcal Q},A)$ for $a$ a single realization of $p$.

If $p\in S(A)$ is stationary and internal to ${\mathcal Q}$ we say that $p$ is {\em fundamental} if some (any) realization of $p$ is already a fundamental system of solutions of $p$ relative to ${\mathcal Q}$.






\section{The local theory}
In this section we focus on internality and analyzabilty with respect to some given collection ${\mathcal Q}$ of partial types, and obtain key results relating rigidity of Galois groups to canonical bases.  In the final section this will be applied to suitable finite rank theories together with a canonical choice for ${\mathcal Q}$.


Recall that we assume the ambient theory to be stable, and let now ${\mathcal Q}$ denote a family of partial types with parameters over a set $A$.
In the proof below we will make use of the fact that (in a stable theory), type-definable groups have canonical parameters, namely for any type-definable group $H$ there is a (small) tuple of parameters $u$ such that an automorphism of the monster model fixes $H$ setwise iff it fixes the tuple $u$.  See Remark 1.6.20 of \cite{PilBook}. Likewise for type-definable homogeneous spaces (namely orbits under type-definable group actions).

Let $G$ be its type-definable over $A$ Galois group relative to ${\mathcal Q}$. Let  $H$ be a
type-definable connected subgroup of $G$, $u$ its canonical parameter,  and let $d$ be the   canonical

\item $u\in {\mathrm{dcl}}(d,A)$

We still fix a family ${\mathcal Q}$ of partial types over a base set of parameters $A$.
We emphasize that by  a {\em (type-)definable Galois group relative to ${\mathcal Q}$} we mean  ${\mathrm{Aut}}(p/{\mathcal Q},B)$ for some stationary complete type $p(x)$ over some set $B$ of parameters which contains $A$.   In general $B, C,\ldots$ will denote sets of parameters containing $A$.

In order to prove the  main result of this section we need to introduce the following from \cite{pal-wag}. First, recall that a stationary type $p$ over $B$ is {\em
analyzable in ${\mathcal Q}$} if for any realization $a$ of $p$ there are
$(a_i:i<\alpha)\in{\mathrm{dcl}}(B,a)$ such that ${\mathrm{tp}}(a_i/B,a_j:j<i)$ is internal to ${\mathcal Q}$ for all $i<\alpha$, and
$a\in{\mathrm{acl}}(B,a_i:i<\alpha)$.
We denote by $\ell_1^{\mathcal Q}(a/A)$ the maximal (possibly infinite) tuple $b$ in ${\mathrm{acl}}(B,a)$ such that ${\mathrm{tp}}(b/B)$ is internal to ${\mathcal Q}$. An inspection of the proof of \cite[Theorem 3.4]{pal-wag} yields:

\begin{fact}\label{FactDomEquiv} The tuple $\ell_1^{\mathcal Q}(a/B)$ dominates $a$ over $B$: whenever $\ell_1^{\mathcal Q}(a/B)$ is independent from $c$ over $B$, then so is $a$.
\end{fact}

Now we can state and prove our main result of this section, which generalizes \cite[Theorem 2.5]{HPP}.

\begin{thm}\label{ThmRigid}
The following are equivalent, where ${\mathcal Q}$ is assumed to be a family of partial types over $A$.
\begin{enumerate}
 \item All Galois groups relative to ${\mathcal Q}$ are rigid.
 \item For any $B$ containing $A$,  if ${\mathrm{tp}}(a/B)$ is analyzable in ${\mathcal Q}$, then for any tuple $c$, ${\mathrm{Cb}}({\mathrm{stp}}(c/B,a))$ is contained in ${\mathrm{acl}}(B,c,{\mathcal Q})$.


\end{enumerate}
\end{thm}
